docs.snippet: Mirroring similar theatrical efforts, Berkeley Rep stages an adaptation of a Sinclair Lewis novel about a vain nominee inveighing against a religious minority....
docs.lead_paragraph: Mirroring similar theatrical efforts, Berkeley Rep stages an adaptation of a Sinclair Lewis novel about a vain nominee inveighing against a religious minority.
docs.abstract: Berkeley Repertory Theater begins previews of play It Can’t Happen Here, adapted from 1935 Sinclair Lewis novel and directed by Lisa Peterson, which eerily reflects political climate surrounding upcoming presidential election; list of other current plays and shows focusing on American presidential campaign highlighted.

headline.main: A Play Timed to Trump’s Candidacy Asks What If
headline.print_headline: In an Election Year, a Play Asks What If

docs.abstract: Speculations ahead of first presidential debate between candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald J Trump predict arguments and outcome of highly anticipated event.

docs.snippet: A pick by President Obama or Hillary Clinton would put Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. in the minority in many close cases, or even nudge him to the left....
docs.lead_paragraph: A pick by President Obama or Hillary Clinton would put Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. in the minority in many close cases, or even nudge him to the left.
docs.abstract: Outcome of presidential election and subsequent appointment of justice to replace late Justice Anton Scalia will offer conservative Supreme Court Chief Justice John G Roberts Jr new chance to define his role and position in court; conservative appointment by Donald Trump would give Roberts chance to lead more assertively, while liberal appointment by Hillary Clinton would offer choice of moving to center or becoming minority figure.

headline.main: Court Leader or Leading Dissenter? Chief Justice’s Fate Tied to Election
headline.print_headline: Leader or Dissenter? Election May Alter Chief Justice’s Role

docs.snippet: In a combative opening debate, Hillary Clinton emphatically denounced Donald Trump Monday night for keeping his personal tax returns and business dealings secret from voters and peddling a "racist lie" about President Barack Obama. Businessman Tru...
docs.lead_paragraph: In a combative opening debate, Hillary Clinton emphatically denounced Donald Trump Monday night for keeping his personal tax returns and business dealings secret from voters and peddling a "racist lie" about President Barack Obama. Businessman Trump repeatedly cast Clinton as a "typical politician" as he sought to capitalize on Americans' frustration with Washington.
